Chapter 5, Part 3: Distinguishing Latent Tendencies. Thus far, latent tendencies and entanglements have been discussed, which the World-Honored One has taught as the contaminants, floods, etc.
Are they only these, or are there others?
Verse:
Due to the distinctions of bonds, etc., there are also said to be five kinds.
Discussion:
The afflictions are also called bonds, fetters, latent tendencies, secondary afflictions, and entanglements, due to distinctions in meaning.
First, what are the bonds?
Verse:
The bonds are nine, such as grasping at objects, etc. Two bonds are established based on grasping at views.
Because two are only unwholesome, and because they arise independently.
Among the entanglements, only jealousy and stinginess are established as two bonds,
Because the two frequently occur, because they are causes of despising and poverty,
Because they universally manifest secondary afflictions, and because they disturb both groups.
Discussion:
There are nine kinds of bonds: the bonds of craving, anger, pride, ignorance, views, grasping, doubt, jealousy, and stinginess.
Among them, the bond of craving refers to the craving of the three realms. The characteristics of the others should be explained as appropriate.
The bond of views refers to the three views. The bond of grasping refers to the two graspings.
Based on this principle, there is a statement:
Are there any dharmas associated with views that are bound by the bond of craving but not bound by the bond of views, and yet where the latent tendency of views still increases?
He said:
Yes.
How so?

Dharmas associated with the two graspings to be eliminated by the truths of cessation and path, when the cognition of the truth of accumulation has arisen but the cognition of the truth of cessation has not yet arisen, are bound by the bond of craving as their object but not bound by the bond of views, because the pervasive bond of views has already been permanently eliminated.
They are not bound by the non-pervasive bond of views, because both the object and association are absent.
However, the latent tendency of views still increases in them, because the latent tendencies of the two graspings increase in them.
Why are the three views established separately as the fetter of views and the two graspings established separately as the fetter of grasping?
Because the three views and the two graspings are the same in substance and in grasping.
That is, the three views are made up of eighteen things, and the two graspings are also the same, so they are said to be the same in substance.
The three are the same in what is grasped, and the two are the same in what grasps, so they are said to be the same in grasping.
Because there is a difference between what is grasped and what grasps, they are established as two fetters.
Why are only two of the entanglements, i.e., jealousy and stinginess, established as fetters, and not the others?
Because only these two are unwholesome and arise autonomously.
That is, only these two are endowed with both of these two meanings, and the others are not. Therefore only two are established.

If the entanglements are only eight, this explanation is reasonable. If ten entanglements are admitted, this explanation is unreasonable, because the two, anger and hypocrisy, are also endowed with both meanings.
Consequently, if it is admitted that there are ten entanglements, it should be said that jealousy and stinginess are grave faults, because these two are frequently active.

Also, two of them can be causes of lowliness and poverty, they manifest as the secondary passions of grief and joy, they disturb the renunciant and householder groups, they disturb gods and asuras, they disturb the two superior destinies of humans and gods, and they disturb both oneself and others.
In other places, the Buddha, in accordance with other classifications, has spoken of five kinds of bonds.
A verse says:
There are also five that accord with the lower part, by two one does not transcend desire,
by three one falls back to the lower, because they include the gate and the root, there are three.
Or one is unwilling to set out, deluded about the path and doubting the path,
one is able to obstruct the quest for liberation, therefore it is said that one only eliminates three.
The treatise says:
What are they?
They are the view of the real existence of the body, attachment to precepts and vows, doubt, desire and greed, and anger.ğŸ”½Why are these five called those that accord with the lower part?
Because these five accord with and benefit the lower part of the realm.
That is, only those of the realm of desire are called the lower portion. These five are able to assist it.
Because the last two are unable to transcend the realm of desire, even if one is able to transcend it, he returns to the lower realm because of the first three, just as a jailer or a guard.
Other masters say:
The term lower portion refers to lower sentient beings, that is, ordinary beings, and the lower realm, that is, the realm of desire.

The first three are able to obstruct the transcendence of lower sentient beings, and the last two are able to prevent the transcendence of the lower realm. Therefore, the five are all called the lower portion.
When one obtains the state of stream-enterer and severs six passions, why does one only say that he severs three bonds?
In principle, one should say that he severs six passions, but because he subsumes the gates and roots, he only says that he severs three.

That is, among those that are severed, there are three kinds. Only one is common to the two, and the four categories are common. Therefore, saying that he severs three kinds subsumes those three gates.

Furthermore, among the objects to be eliminated, the three [wrong views] correspond to the three [afflictions] that are eliminated by the path of cultivation. That is, extreme view corresponds to the view of self, adherence to rules and rituals corresponds to adherence to mere rules and rituals, and wrong view corresponds to doubt.
It is said that eliminating the three [afflictions] includes eliminating the three roots [of non-virtue]. Therefore, it is said that by eliminating the three, the six are eliminated.
There is another explanation:
There are three obstacles for those who want to go to a different place:
First, they do not want to set out;
Second, they rely on wrong paths and lose their way;
Third, they doubt the path.

Those who seek liberation also have similar three obstacles: because of the view of self, they fear liberation and do not want to set out; because of adherence to mere rules and rituals, they rely on wrong paths and lose their way; because of doubt, they deeply doubt the path.
The Buddha shows that the stream-enterer permanently eliminates these obstacles to seeking liberation, and therefore says that by eliminating the three, the six are eliminated.
In other sÅ«tras, the Buddha says that there are also five factors that accord with the upper realms, just as there are with the lower realms.
A verse says:
There are also five factors that accord with the upper realms: attachment to the form and formless realms,
Agitation, pride, and ignorance prevent transcendence of the upper realms.
The treatise says:
When these five are not yet eliminated, they can prevent sentient beings from transcending the upper realms.
Because they accord with and benefit the upper realms, they are called fetters that accord with the upper realms.
The fetters have been explained.
What are the bonds?
The verse says:
The bonds are three due to the three feelings.
The treatise says:
There are three kinds of bonds:ğŸ”½First, the bond of craving, which refers to all craving;
second, the bond of hatred, which refers to all hatred;
third, the bond of ignorance, which refers to all ignorance.
Why are only these three said to be bonds?
The bonds are said to be three due to the three feelings.
That is to say, in relation to the feeling of pleasure, the bond of craving increases, because it increases both in terms of the object and in terms of association.
In relation to the feeling of pain, hatred; in relation to the feeling of indifference, ignorance, should be understood in the same way.
Although craving and hatred also exist in relation to the feeling of indifference, it is not like ignorance.
In terms of one's own continuity, the three feelings of pleasure, etc. are the objects of bondage, and this is definitely said.
The bonds have already been distinguished.
What are the latent afflictions?
Verse:
The latent afflictions have already been explained.
Commentary:
The latent afflictions are either six, or seven, or ten, or ninety-eight, as already explained.
Since the latent afflictions have already been explained.
What are the secondary afflictions?
Verse:
The secondary afflictions are the rest of the defiled mental activities included in the aggregate of mental activities.
Commentary:
These afflictions are also called secondary afflictions, because they all disturb the mind as an event.

There are also the rest that are different from the afflictions, defiled mental activities included in the aggregate of mental activities, because they arise following the secondary afflictions, they are also called secondary afflictions, but they are not called afflictions because they are not fundamental.
Their characteristics are extensively listed in the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama, and will be briefly discussed later.
As for the category of entanglements, afflictions, and defilements, one should first explain the characteristics of the entanglements.
The verse says:
The entanglements are eight: shamelessness, lack of conscience, jealousy, stinginess, regret, drowsiness,
And agitation, torpor, or ten by adding anger and concealment.
Shamelessness, stinginess, and agitation all arise from craving,
Lack of conscience, drowsiness, and torpor arise from ignorance,
Jealousy and anger arise from hatred, and regret arises from doubt and concealment.
The treatise says:
The fundamental afflictions are also called entanglements, because the sÅ«tras say that the entanglements of craving for desire are a condition.
However, the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra-Å›Ästra says there are eight entanglements, and the VaibhÄá¹£ika school says there are ten entanglements, adding anger and concealment to the previous eight.
Shamelessness and lack of conscience have already been explained above.
Jealousy means not being happy in one's heart at others' prosperity.
Stinginess means being stingy and attached in one's heart due to the incompatibility of skillfully giving away wealth and the Dharma.
Regret is the same as remorse, as has already been explained above.
Sleepiness is by nature the dullness and sluggishness that cause the mind to lose consciousness and be unable to grasp the body.
The two entanglements of remorse and sleepiness only take on defiled forms.
Agitation and torpor are explained as before.
Except for anger and harmfulness, the mind is said to be agitated when it is directed toward sentient beings and nonsentient things.
Concealment of one's own faults is called concealment.

Among these ten kinds of entanglements, shamelessness, stinginess, and agitation are the same as craving. Shame, sleepiness, and torpor are the same as ignorance. Jealousy and anger are the same as hatred. Remorse is the same as doubt.
Some say:
Concealment is the same as craving.
Some say:
It is the same as ignorance.
Some say:
It is the same as both.
There is knowledge and ignorance, in the order in which they occur.
What are the characteristics of the other afflictive hindrances?
Verse:
The six afflictive hindrances are vexation, harmfulness, resentment, deceit, flattery, and arrogance.
Deceit and arrogance arise from craving, harm and resentment arise from hatred,
annoyance arises from the view of grasping at inferior views as supreme, and flattery arises from the various views.
The treatise says:
annoyance means stubbornly grasping at one's own faults, because of this one does not accept proper admonitions.
harm means being able to oppress others, because of this one is able to engage in beating, scolding, and other such acts.
resentment means repeatedly pondering the matters that one is angry about, and not letting go of one's grudges.
flattery means the mind is crooked, because of this one is unable to reveal oneself as one really is, either falsely denying or setting up skillful means to make one's understanding unclear.
deception means confusing others.
arrogance has already been explained above.
these six kinds arise from afflictions, and because their defiled characteristics are coarse, they are called the stains of afflictions.

among these six kinds of stains of afflictions, deception and arrogance are the outflow of craving, harm and resentment are the outflow of hatred, annoyance is the outflow of the view of grasping at inferior views as supreme, and flattery is the outflow of the various views.
it is said, what is crooked?
Because they are the outflow of the various wrong views. These defilements and entanglements arise from the passions, and therefore they are all called secondary passions.

translated: To which class of passions are these defilements and entanglements to be eliminated by insight and to which are they to be eliminated by cultivation?
The Treatise says that
among the ten entanglements, shamelessness, etc., are eliminated by both insight and cultivation, because they arise in association with the passions of both classes.
They are called eliminated by insight into a truth when they are associated with the passions eliminated by insight into that truth.

The remaining five entanglements, jealousy, stinginess, etc., and the secondary passions are eliminated only by cultivation, because they are only associated with the power of the passions eliminated by cultivation.
They are called autonomous because they are only associated with the power of the ignorance eliminated by cultivation.
To which moral natures do these secondary passions belong?
The Treatise says that
The three of desire, two in the upper realms, and the rest are evil.
The treatise says:
In the desire realm, the three of sleep, torpor, and agitation are both unwholesome and indeterminate. The rest are all unwholesome.
In the two upper realms, all that exist are categorized as only indeterminate.
To which realm do these secondary afflictions belong?
A verse says:
Flattery and deception exist in the desire realm and first meditation. The three exist in the three realms. The rest exist in the desire realm.
A treatise says:
Flattery and deception exist only in the desire realm and first meditation.
How do we know that flattery and deception exist in the Brahma world?
Because the Great Brahma King concealed his own feelings and used signs to deceive and delude the bhiká¹£u AÅ›vajit.
Although these two have already been distinguished above, because their meaning is related, they are now discussed again.
The three of torpor, agitation, and pride exist in the three realms. The rest all exist only in the desire realm.
The five are as previously explained. The remaining eleven are only bound to the desire realm.
The latent afflictions and secondary afflictions have been explained.
Among them, how many are only in the mental ground?
How many are common to the six consciousnesses?
Verse:
The latent afflictions of pride and sleepiness in the stage of insight, the autonomous secondary afflictions,
All arise only in the mental ground, the rest are common to the six consciousnesses.
Commentary:
In brief, it should be known that all those eliminated by insight and those eliminated by cultivation,
All the autonomous latent afflictions of pride and sleepiness, arise in the mental consciousness. Because they do not occur in the five consciousnesses.

The rest all occur in the six consciousnesses. That is, desire, anger, ignorance, and the secondary afflictions associated with them, namely shamelessness, lack of conscience, torpor, restlessness, and the other secondary afflictions included in the great grounds of affliction, because they all occur in the six consciousnesses.
As previously explained, the five faculties such as pleasure, now, in this discussion, what afflictions and secondary afflictions are associated with which faculties?
Here, one should first discuss the various afflictions.
A verse says:
In the desire realm, all afflictions are associated with craving, joy, and pleasure.
Anger is associated with sorrow, suffering, and delusion is universal. Wrong views are associated with sorrow and joy.
Doubt is associated with sorrow, and the other five are associated with joy. All are associated with equanimity.
In the upper realms, they all correspond to their own consciousnesses and various feelings.
The treatise says:
Among the afflictions bound to the desire realm, craving is associated with joy and pleasure, because it arises with a joyful mode of activity and pervades the six consciousnesses.
Anger is associated with sorrow and suffering, because it arises with a sorrowful mode of activity and pervades the six consciousnesses.
Ignorance is universally associated with the previous four, because it arises with both joyful and sorrowful modes of activity and pervades the six consciousnesses.
Wrong views are associated with both sorrow and joy, because they arise with both joyful and sorrowful modes of activity and are only in the mental realm.
Why do wrong views arise with both joyful and sorrowful modes of activity?
Because they respectively first create sinful and meritorious actions.

Doubt is associated with sorrow, because it evolves with a sorrowful mode of activity and occurs only in the realm of manas. Because the mind of one who harbors doubt seeks to determine the truth and is sorrowful.
The remaining four views and pride are associated with joy, because they evolve with a joyful mode of activity and occur only in the realm of manas.
We have now discussed the association of the passions with feeling according to their specific characteristics.

If we discuss their association with feeling according to their general characteristics, all are associated with the feeling of indifference, because when the continuity of the passions is severed, their power declines and they necessarily abide in indifference.
Since this is the case in the realm of desire, what about the upper two realms ?

All are associated with the feelings of their own realms, in accordance with their proper categories, and with the consciousnesses of their own realms.ğŸ”½If a realm has all four consciousnesses, then the passions that are generated by each of the consciousnesses are associated with the feelings of that consciousness.
If the various realms have only mental consciousness, then the passions that are generated by mental consciousness are associated with the feelings of that consciousness.
The amount of consciousness and feeling in the upper stages has already been discussed above, so they are not discussed separately here.
We have already discussed the association of the various passions with feelings. We now must discuss the secondary passions.
A verse says:
Among the secondary passions, jealousy, regret, resentment, and vexationğŸ”½arise with sorrow. Harm and hatred arise with sorrow. Stinginess is associated with the feeling of joy.
Crafty flattery, sleep, and posturing are associated with sorrow and joy.
Arrogance is associated with joy, happiness, and indifference. The remaining four are universally associated.
The treatise says:

Among the secondary passions, the six kinds beginning with jealousy are all associated with the faculty of sorrow, because they evolve from the action of sorrow and are found only in the realm of manas.
Stinginess is associated with joy, because it evolves from the action of delight and is found only in the realm of manas.
Evolves from the action of delight means that the characteristics of stinginess are extremely similar to those of craving.
Crafty flattery, sleep, and posturing are associated with sorrow and joy, because they evolve from the actions of both sorrow and delight and are found only in the realm of manas.
The mode of activity of joy and dejection is that sometimes one practices deceit, etc., with a joyful mind, and sometimes one practices with a sorrowful mind.
Arrogance is associated with joy and satisfaction, and the mode of activity of joy is that of the mind alone.
It is associated with satisfaction in the third trance state, and if it is in the stages below that, it is associated with joy.

The above-mentioned secondary passions are all associated with the feeling of indifference, because when the continuity is cut off, one rests in indifference, and because there is a universal activity in the stage of indifference alone.
Indifference is associated with all, without obstruction, because it is like ignorance, which is associated with all.

The remaining four, shamelessness, lack of conscience, sloth, and distraction, are all associated with the five feelings, because the first two are categorized as great ground of nongood, and the last two are categorized as great ground of defilement.
Among the passions and secondary passions that have been discussed, the Buddha has said that some are called hindrances on the basis of other characteristics.
Now we must explain them.
What are the characteristics of the hindrances?
A verse says:
The five hindrances are only in the desire realm, because food, antidotes, and functions are the same.
Although there are two, they are established as one hindrance, because they obstruct the aggregates, there are only five.
The treatise says:

The Buddha said in the sutras that there are five hindrances: the hindrance of desire and greed, the hindrance of anger, the hindrance of torpor and sleep, the hindrance of restlessness and remorse, and the hindrance of doubt.
Among them, torpor, restlessness, and doubt mentioned here, are they like desire, greed, anger, sleep, and remorse, only in the desire realm?
Or are they common to the three realms?
One should know that these three are also only in the desire realm, because the sutras say that these five are purely complete unwholesome aggregates.
The form and formless realms do not have unwholesomeness, but because these five are purely unwholesome, they are only in the desire realm, not in the form or formless realms.
Why are the two hindrances of torpor and sleep, and restlessness and remorse, each with two natures, combined to establish one?
Because food, antidotes, and functions are the same, they are combined to establish one.
Food refers to what is eaten, also called provisions.
To cure means to be able to cure, and is also called not to be food.
To use means to have a function, and is also called ability.
Because of this, the sutra says:
Although drowsiness and sleep are two, their food and non-food are the same.
What is called the food of the drowsiness and sleep hindrances?
It refers to five kinds of dharmas:
1. Drowsiness, 2. Displeasure, 3. Yawning, 4. Unevenness in eating, 5. Dullness and inferiority of the mind.
What is called the non-food of this hindrance?
It refers to the thought of brightness.
These two kinds have the same function, which is to both cause the nature of the mind to be dull and obscure.
Although restlessness and remorse are two, their food and non-food are the same.
What is called the food of the restlessness and remorse hindrances?
It refers to four kinds of dharmas:
1. Thoughts about relatives, 2. Thoughts about the country, 3. Thoughts of immortality, 4. Thoughts of the various things one has experienced in the past, such as play, laughter, joy, and service.
What is called the non-food of this hindrance?
It refers to Å›amatha.
The two kinds of things and functions are also the same, because both can cause the mind to be not tranquil.
Therefore, food, treatment, and function are the same, so torpor and sleep and restlessness and remorse are combined into one.
All afflictions and so forth have the meaning of covering. Why did the TathÄgata only speak of these five?
Only these five can be the supreme obstacles to the five aggregates.

The covers of craving and aversion can obstruct the aggregate of morality, while torpor and sleep can obstruct the aggregate of wisdom. Restlessness and remorse can obstruct the aggregate of concentration. Because of the absence of concentration and wisdom, one has doubts about the four truths. Because of doubt, one is unable to give rise to liberation, the knowledge and vision of liberation. Therefore, only these five are established as covers.

If one explains the meaning of the sÅ«tra in this way, restlessness and remorse should be said before torpor and sleep, because wisdom must arise based on concentration. The obstacle to concentration should also be the obstacle to wisdom first, because of this principle.
Based on this principle, another teacher says:
Among these five hindrances, torpor and sleep and agitation and remorse respectively obstruct the aggregate of concentration and the aggregate of wisdom. For this reason, the scriptures say:
â€œOne who cultivates samÄdhi fears torpor and sleep, and one who cultivates discernment of dharmas fears agitation and remorse.â€
Some others explain it differently,
saying that there are only five causes.
What do they say?

They say that in the stage of practice, one first grasps the two aspects of what is lovable and what is hateful among various objects such as form, etc. Later, in the stage of abiding, due to those as causes, one then gives rise to the two hindrances of desire and hatred.

These two are able to obstruct the mind that is about to enter samÄdhi. Because of this, later when one is actually entering the stage of samÄdhi, one is unable to practice tranquility and insight correctly.
Because of this, one then gives rise to torpor and sleep and agitation and remorse, which respectively obstruct Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ and prevent them from arising.
Because of this, when one later emerges from the stage of samÄdhi and reflects on the dharmas, doubt becomes an obstruction again. Therefore, the establishment of the hindrances is only these five.

Now we should consider: when the contaminants that are pervasive in other realms and that are eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of cessation and path, and the contaminants that have impure objects are eliminated, one does not know their objects at the time of eliminating them. When one knows their objects, they are not eliminated.
By what causes are these contaminants eliminated?
It is not necessary to eliminate them by means of universal knowledge of their objects.
If that is so, by how many causes in general are contaminants eliminated?
They are eliminated by four causes.
What are the four?
The verse states:
Because of the universal knowledge of objects, because of eliminating their objects,
Because of eliminating their objects, because of the arising of the antidote, they are eliminated.
The treatise states:

First, as for the elimination of contaminants eliminated by insight, it is by means of the first three causes.ğŸ”½First, because of the universal knowledge of objects, they are eliminated. This refers to the contaminants eliminated by insight into the truths of suffering and accumulation that have objects in their own realm, and the contaminants eliminated by insight into the truths of cessation and path that have pure objects.

Second, because of eliminating their objects, they are eliminated. This refers to the contaminants eliminated by insight into the truths of suffering and accumulation that have objects in other realms. Because those that have objects in their own realm can have them as objects, if their objects are eliminated, they are also eliminated.

The third is that which is eliminated by eliminating its object, that is, the impure views of the realm of desire that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truths and by the path of cultivation of the truths, because the pure views that take these impure views as their objects can be their antidote. When the object is eliminated, the impure views are also eliminated.
The fourth is that which is eliminated by the arising of the antidote, that is, the impure views of the realm of desire that are eliminated by the path of cultivation of the truths.
When the antidote to a class of impure views arises, then all the impure views of that class are suddenly eliminated.

What class of impure views is the antidote to what class of impure views?ğŸ”½The antidote to the strongest of the strong class of impure views is the weakest of the weak class of the path of insight into the truths.
The antidote to the weakest of the weak class of impure views is the strongest of the strong class of the path of insight into the truths.
This principle will be discussed in detail later.
How many kinds of antidotes are there in all?
A verse says:
There are four kinds of antidotes: elimination, upholding, distance, and disgust.
The treatise says:
In general, there are four kinds of antidotes.
The first is the antidote of elimination, which is the uninterrupted path.
The second is the antidote of maintaining, that is, the subsequent path, because it is able to maintain the possession of this abandonment.
The third is the antidote of distancing, that is, the path that exists after the path of liberation, because that path is able to make the possession of the abandoned passions more distant.
Other masters say:
It is also the path of liberation, because the path of liberation, like that, is able to make the possession of the abandoned passions more distant.
The fourth is the antidote of disgust, that is, if there is a path that, seeing the faults of this realm, deeply generates disgust.
However, if this antidote is to be well explained, in principle it should be in the following order:
The first is the antidote of disgust, that is, the path of added effort that takes suffering and its cause as objects.
The second is the antidote of cutting off, that is, that which takes all as objects and generates the path of immediate succession.
The third is the antidote of maintaining, that is, that which takes all as objects and generates the path of liberation.
The fourth is the antidote of distancing, that is, that which takes all as objects and generates the path of added effort.
Is the definitive abandonment of all passions definitely from what?
The verse says:
It should be known that from the object, the various afflictions can be made to be eliminated.
The treatise says:

It should be known that when the afflictions are permanently eliminated, it is impossible to make them separate from the associated dharmas. It is only possible to make them far removed from the object, because they are no longer produced with regard to the object.
The principle of eliminating future afflictions can be so, because it is possible to make them no longer produced with regard to the object.
How is it said that past afflictions are eliminated?
If it is said that the verse speaks of the object, the meaning is that because the object is completely known, they are eliminated.
This is also unreasonable, because it is not definite.

For this reason, it should be said that the elimination of afflictions and so forth is definitely from what. The elimination of afflictions and so forth in one's own continuity is due to the elimination of the attainment.

The afflictions and so forth in the continuity of others, and all uncontaminated dharmas such as form, are eliminated due to the final elimination of the various afflictions in one's own continuity that are able to take them as objects.
How many kinds of remoteness are there in what is called remoteness?
In verse, it is said:
There are four kinds of remoteness, namely characteristic, antidote, place, and time,
Like the great elements and morality, in different places and the two times, etc.
The treatise says:
It is said that remoteness is generally of four kinds:
1. Remoteness of characteristics, like the four great elements. Although they are born together in one aggregate, they are also called remote because their characteristics are different.
2. Remoteness of antidotes, like upholding precepts and violating precepts. Although they are both practiced in one body, they are also called remote because they are antidotes to each other.
3. Remoteness of place, like the eastern and western oceans. Although they are both in one world, they are also called remote because of the separation of their locations.
4. Remoteness of time, like the past and future times. Although they are both established based on one dharma, they are also called remote because of the separation of time.
With respect to what is it said to be remote?
With respect to the present time.
When it has just ceased or is about to arise, it is adjacent to the present. How can it be called remote?
Because of the difference in the nature of the three times, the present is called distant. It is not that only the distant past and future are called distant.
If this is so, then the present should also be called distant, because it is also different from the past and future in nature.
If you say that the past and future are called distant because they lack activity, apart from activity, then unconditioned dharmas are said to be without activity. How can they be called near?
If you say that unconditioned dharmas are called near because they are universally obtained in the present, then the two times of past and future should be the same.
How can unconditioned space be called near?
If you say that the past and future are called distant because they are separated from each other by the present,

and the present is called near because it is adjacent to the two times and because unconditioned dharmas are not separated from it, then the past and future should be adjacent to the present, because they are both separated from each other. Therefore, they should be called both distant and near, and it is not proper to say that they are only distant.

If we rely on correct principles, we should say that the past and future are distant because they are separated from the present characteristics of dharmas. The future has not yet obtained the characteristics of dharmas, and the past has already abandoned the characteristics of dharmas.
